#### Section 1: Invisible worlds
Materials and phenomena that occur on the nanoscale are, almost by
definition, too small for the human visual sense. Nevertheless, we
really do know their shapes, sizes, and compositions. To obtain this
information, we rely on techniques of **characterization**. Namely, on
the two closely related areas of **spectroscopy** and *imaging*.
Spectroscopy is the processes by which matter is bombarded with some
type of particle or radiation, and the particles that are scattered,
transmitted, or re-emitted are analyzed for clues about the structure.
Imaging techniques use a similar paradigm, but the end goal is not to
produce a quantitative spectrum but a visual image for processing (often
by the human brain). There are many modalities which combine
spectroscopy and imaging in a single instrument. For a video primer to
this chapter, visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/N18UhNQmI8o)

One of the things that differentiates science from everyday rational
behavior is that science needs special tools to overcome the limits of
human senses. We can only learn so much about the world from our senses
of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste. While we can determine some
things about the structure and properties of matter from our five basic
senses, we need to correlate these observations to information gleaned
from other tools. Nowhere is the augmentation of human senses more
necessary than in nanoengineering, where everything is way too small to
see with even the most powerful optical microscopes. For example, a
nanoparticle or quantum dot might have a diameter of 5 nm, but the
smallest wavelength of light that can be detected by the human eye is
about 400 nm, which corresponds to violet light. So, we are blind to
nanomaterials. That's why we can't see viruses billowing out of people's
mouths and noses, and it's also why we can't see the intricate details
of a computer microprocessor at the level of the transistor, even under
the highest possible magnification with a conventional microscope.

Thus, there is a conundrum posed by the diffraction limit of light. The
way to circumvent this problem is to use particles other than visible
photons, such as electrons, ultraviolet rays, X-rays, or even helium
nuclei. These approaches are analogous to optical microscopy in that
they use wavelike particles to interact with matter, and the image is
created from the ways in which light is absorbed or scattered from the
surface.

Such methods of obtaining images of nanoscale objects are not limited
only to modalities which shine---or blast---light or particles upon the
sample. The other major way in which information is collected about the
composition and structure of nanoscale materials is not by shining a
beam from a distance, but rather by physical contact or near-physical
contact, in methods that are akin not to the sense of vision but to the
sense of touch. Such approaches are referred to collectively as
"scanning probe" techniques. The feature that all scanning probe
instruments have in common is the use of a sharp object which scans
along a surface (like a vinyl or LP player). The tip can be used to plot
the topography, mechanical properties, conductivity, chemical
composition, or other properties of the surface. Finally, there are
techniques which use radiation not to generate images, but to probe the
structure of atoms, molecules, particles, and surfaces. These
spectroscopic modalities rely on the basic physics we have covered in
detail in Chapter 8, so we will begin here.
